context: This observation excludes the possibility that the differences observed in the exhaled breath VOCs between the CKD and control animals were caused by defecation within the chamber. The study revealed the presence of 56 VOCs in the exhaled breath at different concentrations when compared to the air used to flush the glass chamber, and 36 VOCs released from the cultured stools in the rats. Among the VOCs detected in the exhaled breath, the relative abundance of four gases was significantly different between the CKD and control animals. In particular exhaled breath isoprene level markedly increased within one week following subtotal nephrectomy and remained elevated throughout the observation period pointing to increased production of this compound in animals with renal failure. The mechanism by which CKD increases production of isoprene in the study animals is unknown. However several in vivo and in vitro studies have shown that isoprene is a byproduct of cholesterol biosynthesis. The rate-limiting step in cholesterol synthesis is catalyzed by 3-hydroxy-3-methyl-glutaryl coenzyme A (HMG4-CoA) reductase which reduces HMG-CoA to mevalonate and CoA.
